column3: Take a trip down the red, white and blue memory lane. What a difference a decade can make in politics!
column8: Who says conservatives can't be inclusive? At the 2004 Republican convention in NYC, Youth Radio found some punks with an appreciation for George W. himself.
column15: Back in  2008, Senator Barack Obama was a Presidential hopeful running a fresh campaign based on hope. Hear young people at the Democratic National Convention react to that promise.
column22: In a stunning political upset, Donald J.Trump became President #45 -- with many liberals still asking, “What just happened?”

column3: MySpace vs. Snapchat, livejournal vs. group text. Listen to find your spot along teen tech culture divides
column6: A Video Game Addict Reviews The Sega Dreamcast
column8: It’s a step up from the N64, but will the Sega Dreamcast video game console last the test of time? This gamer review takes you back to simpler times.
column15: The teen trend in 2008? Moving from email to Facebook wall posts. From the early days of social media receipts.
column22: An introduction to the then-brand new app Snapchat -- listen to teens reassure adults it’s not ALL about the d**k pics.

column3: Looking back on the last few generations of teen fashion trends… some things stood the test of time better than others.
column8: “It’s all about that button fly.” And according to one '90s teen, this classic jean brand was simply past its prime.
column15: Forget matching your shirt color with your shoe hue. In 2008, it was all about knee-high rainbow socks and candy-colored hair extension.
column20: Teens say looks can be liberating despite fashion police
column22: Social media isn't the only place teens feel the pressure to look good. The high school hallway is also place where your look can lift you up, or bring you down.

column3: Teens of every generation know: it’s not just what you say, it’s how you say it.
column8: High Schooler Sanovia Jackson rang in 2004 by talking with NPR host Melissa Block what slang phrases were in and out the new year.
column15: In 2007, NPR asked a bunch of people to weigh in on the n-word -- including this group of Bay Area teens.
column20: What’s The Meaning Of The Gun Emoji?
column22: They say a picture can be worth a thousand words. But what happens when that picture is a tiny gun you sometimes use to text your friends?

column3: From radio to MTV to YouTube, every generation finds a way to get its groove on.
column8: MTV was at the height of fashion and music… for the ‘90s. Youth Radio listened in on an MTV VJ audition in 1999.
column13: Basketball beef spills into rap world
column15: The 2008 NBA finals pitted the Celtics against the Lakers. But off the court, the season's biggest basketball dust-up was between DeShawn Stevenson and LeBron James — and their rap proxies, Soulja Boy and Jay-Z.
column20: Punks Are The New Mall Rats
column22: "Meet me at the mall" isn’t really a thing anymore… unless you’re talking about the punk music scene in Stockton, California.
